p: Dipyridamole binds Mpro through hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions, showing an inhibitory effect (IC 50 of 0.55 μM) better than other drugs tested, such as the disulfiram (4.67 μM), which was taken as positive control for the bioassay [158]. Furthermore, dipyridamole and montelukast sodium showed a global inhibitory function on NF-kB signalling and inflammatory responses during viral infection [158].
